subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
Found in certain southern dialects (chiefly {{der|cmn|yue|-}}) as the colloquial word for “man” (for example, in the term {{m|zh|肥佬}}). Probably related to {{cog|za|raeuz|raeuz ~ laeuz|we; also a demonym: {{w|Rau peoples}}}}, a widespread Tai word meaning “we; people” ({{cog|tai-pro|*rawᴬ}}).

''{{w|zh:廣東新語|Guangdong Xinyu}}'' {{defdate|1678}} has the following passage:
{{zh-x|^廣州 謂 平人 曰 佬，亦 曰 獠，賤稱 也。|People in Guangzhou call “common people” ''lau'' or ''leu'' (derogatory).|collapsed=y}}

Also compare {{cog|hmn-pro|*ʔljuwᴮ||male}} ({{cog|mww|lau||male}}), {{cog|mkh-kat-pro|*-law||man}}, as well as {{cog|lo|ລາວ||Lao < people}}, {{cog|th|ลาว}}.

subSections.title: Pronunciation
Definitions
Usage notes
subSections.text:
* In Cantonese, when it is used as a standalone word, it usually refers to a [[middle-aged]] man.
* Mainly used as a colloquial suffix to denote “[[-er]]”.
